image.altText: A helicopter dropping water onto a bushfire.

props.synopsis: Under the new system, parts of Australia have already faced catastrophic warnings this fire season. But some of those alerts were wrong.

title.children: Australia's new $11m fire warning system is exaggerating the risks, ABC investigation reveals

image.altText: A woman with long dark hair in a pharmacist uniform smiling at the camera inside a chemist.

props.synopsis: Antibiotics to treat urinary tract infections could soon be available from South Australian pharmacies without a doctor's prescription after a parliamentary inquiry.

title.children: Pharmacists could soon be given the power to prescribe UTI medication in South Australia

image.altText: A shirtless man about to be arrested by police on the side of a road.

props.synopsis: A South Australian CFS volunteer is found guilty of lighting the Cherry Gardens bushfire in 2021that destroyed two home and razed almost 3,000 hectares.

title.children: Former CFS volunteer found guilty of lighting Adelaide Hills bushfires

props.synopsis: Under a massive shake-up of Defence Forces, roughly 800 army personnel will move out of Adelaide — but SA will become the home of advanced land-based, long-range strike capabilities.

title.children: Troops move out but SA becomes home of long-range strike capabilities in Defence Forces shake up

props.synopsis: The state's health authorities says there is no link to a previous outbreak in the Anangu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara (APY) Lands and no risk to the wider community.

title.children: Five active tuberculosis cases identified in South Australia's Murraylands region, including young child

image.altText: A man sits at a table covered in drinks as he waves a cigarette in his hand.

props.synopsis: A powerful village chief invited dozens of police officers to his house for a wild party. But when one of them wound up dead, it kicked off a huge scandal that threatens the unchecked power of Thailand’s authorities.

title.children: A Thai village chief invited dozens of cops for dinner. Then he allegedly told his henchman to kill one

image.altText: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese wearing a Yes hooded sweatshirt during a press conference.

props.synopsis: This week we witnessed the beginning of managing expectations when Anthony Albanese started framing what he might say if the nation votes No on October 14, writes Patricia Karvelas.

title.children: It's brutal Politics 101, but Albanese is already prepping for the day after the referendum

image.altText: Geoffrey Blainey makes a hand gesture while delivering a speech

props.synopsis: In an opinion piece published in The Australian, historian Geoffrey Blainey said Indigenous people were counted in every federal census since 1901. Is that correct? RMIT ABC Fact Check investigates.

title.children: We fact checked Geoffrey Blainey on counting Indigenous people in the census. Here's what we found

image.altText: A drone shot of people on an island

props.synopsis: On a remote beach in Solomon Islands, family members sort out their differences with spears.

title.children: These families settle their disputes with spears. Then the chief wades into the water

image.altText: An illustration of a particle and an antiparticle in purple and orange

props.synopsis: Attempts to understand why there is much more matter in the Universe than antimatter have been dealt a blow with an experiment ruling out one of the major explanations.

title.children: 'A huge puzzle': Antimatter falls just like ordinary matter, leaving the Universe's biggest mystery unsolved

image.altText: A for sale sign outside a suburban home

props.synopsis: A "slight uptick" in inflation is unlikely to see the Reserve Bank lift rates at its October meeting, but households facing a fixed-rate mortgage cliff are warned to brace for higher repayments.

title.children: Half a million households brace for higher interest rates by the end of the year as the mortgage cliff looms

image.altText: A black and white collage of two women - one with short hair and one with long hair - looking at the camera

props.synopsis: Some of the disability royal commission's most compelling evidence has come from mothers who lost their children. On the eve of the final report, two mums share their stories and hopes for the future.

title.children: Nella's daughter died in disability care. She wants to make sure no-one else goes through the same pain

image.altText: A sky light pops through the grass.

props.synopsis: Designers of "earth-sheltered" homes say interest in living underground is rising as the risk of bushfires increases and more days of extreme heat are forecast.

title.children: Why more of us are opting to live underground to escape bushfires and extreme heat

image.altText: A man lies in hospital with a tube coming from his nose

props.synopsis: Critically ill surfing great Mark Richardson has been medically evacuated from an Indonesian hospital to Darwin after efforts to transport donations of the rare A negative blood type proved unsuccessful.

title.children: Surfing great arrives in Australia as 'clinically complicated' evacuation comes in nick of time

image.altText: Donald Trump Ivanka, Melania, Barron, and Don Jr stand together looking solemn

props.synopsis: A New York judge has ruled that former US president Donald Trump committed fraud when he lied about his wealth for a decade, defrauding banks and insurers as he built his real estate empire. So what is his real net worth?

title.children: Donald Trump's latest legal loss won't send him to prison. But it's a major financial setback for him and his family

image.altText: Flames above a large battery box behind a fence at night time

props.synopsis: E-scooters, e-bikes and renewable energy storage in the form of batteries are rapidly increasing in popularity, but they’re creating another problem.

title.children: Lithium batteries are increasing in popularity, but they're creating another problem

image.altText: Malaysian mother and daughter standing together.

props.synopsis: The family of Adelaide woman Annapuranee Jenkins, whose remains were found on a Malaysian construction site in 2020, says a review of coronial inquest findings is being thwarted by a lack of cooperation.

title.children: Family of mum buried on Malaysian building site says judicial process is stalling

image.altText: A man in a suit, seen from behind, looks at the ASX share price boards.

props.synopsis: Australia's stock market is expected to have a lacklustre morning after another mixed session on Wall Street overnight.

title.children: Local market tipped to open lower, new retail trade and job vacancies data to come

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The market opened at 10am, and the index has lost a bit of value already, as the futures suggested it would.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Market slips in early trade

children.content: The market opened at 10am, and the index has lost a bit of value already, as the futures suggested it would.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Liquor & Gaming NSW has issued a press release this morning. It says wagering giant Tabcorp Holdings Limited has been convicted and fined $15,000 for offering an inducement to people without a TAB betting account. It refers to a matter that was heard in the Downing Centre Local Court in Sydney last Friday, September 22. Here's the bulk of the release: The magistrate found Tabcorp advertised a promotion via its website which included an inducement to participate in a gambling activity. In New South Wales, it is an offence to publish or communicate inducement advertisements to non-account holders. As a result of an internal failing, Tabcorp inadvertently caused its website to communicate a gambling inducement to non-account holders, which is an offence in NSW. The Liquor & Gaming NSW executive director regulatory operations, Jane Lin, said the regulator will continue to take a zero-tolerance approach to the publication of illegal gambling inducements. "Tabcorp is a large corporation and it is our expectation that an operator of this scale has strong internal controls and demonstrates greater vigilance to prevent members of the public being exposed to gambling inducements," Ms Lin said. "In many cases gambling promotions can be legally offered to betting account holders who, unlike the general public, have made a conscious decision to open an account and have expressly consented to receive this information. "However, wagering operators can't advertise or promote inducements such as offers of increased odds or bonus bets to entice people to open a betting account or to gamble more frequently." NSW bans the advertisement of any offer of an inducement to participate in a gambling activity, including an inducement to bet more frequently. It is also prohibited to offer any inducements to open betting accounts, refer friends to open betting accounts, keep a betting account open or consent to receive gambling advertising.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: TAB convicted and fined for offering gambling inducement

children.content: Liquor
Gaming NSW
has issued a press release this morning.
It says wagering giant
Tabcorp Holdings Limited
has been convicted and fined $15,000 for offering an inducement to people without a TAB betting account.
It refers to a matter that was heard in the Downing Centre Local Court in Sydney last Friday, September 22.
Here's the bulk of the release:
The magistrate found Tabcorp advertised a promotion via its website which included an inducement to participate in a gambling activity.

In New South Wales, it is an offence to publish or communicate inducement advertisements to non-account holders. As a result of an internal failing, Tabcorp inadvertently caused its website to communicate a gambling inducement to non-account holders, which is an offence in NSW.
The Liquor
Gaming NSW executive director regulatory operations, Jane Lin,
said the regulator will continue to take a zero-tolerance approach to the publication of illegal gambling inducements.

"Tabcorp is a large corporation and it is our expectation that an operator of this scale has strong internal controls and demonstrates greater vigilance to prevent members of the public being exposed to gambling inducements," Ms Lin said.

"In many cases gambling promotions can be legally offered to betting account holders who, unlike the general public, have made a conscious decision to open an account and have expressly consented to receive this information.
"However, wagering operators can't advertise or promote inducements such as offers of increased odds or bonus bets to entice people to open a betting account or to gamble more frequently."
NSW bans the advertisement of any offer of an inducement to participate in a gambling activity, including an inducement to bet more frequently.
It is also prohibited to offer any inducements to open betting accounts, refer friends to open betting accounts, keep a betting account open or consent to receive gambling advertising.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Some of the country's biggest companies are at war with each other over the rocketing cost of gas in Western Australia, where prices have eclipsed even those in the eastern states. Giant conglomerate Wesfarmers and miner South32 are among a group of corporate heavyweights calling for a shake-up of WA's vaunted domestic gas reservation policy amid claims it is being largely ignored by some producers. Wesfarmers has taken the extraordinary step of singling out Australia's biggest oil and gas producer Woodside, accusing it of failing to deliver adequate quantities of gas from its $12 billion Pluto project. Daniel Mercer has the story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wesfarmers takes aim at Woodside amid rocketing gas prices in Western Australia

featuredLink.title: Claims of exploitation and 'absurd' tactics as corporate heavyweights go to war over WA gas prices

children.content: Some of the country's biggest companies are at war with each other over the rocketing cost of gas in Western Australia, where prices have eclipsed even those in the eastern states.

Giant conglomerate Wesfarmers and miner South32 are among a group of corporate heavyweights calling for a shake-up of WA's vaunted domestic gas reservation policy amid claims it is being largely ignored by some producers.

Wesfarmers has taken the extraordinary step of singling out Australia's biggest oil and gas producer Woodside, accusing it of failing to deliver adequate quantities of gas from its $12 billion Pluto project.
Daniel Mercer has the story here:
